questions.question:
Question 1: A 50-year-old man who developed myocardial infarction 3 days ago now presents with 
jaundice. Lab investigations done are given below. Which region of the liver lobule is most 
likely affected here?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hepatocellular injury due to ischemia. Zone 3 
(centrilobular zone) of the liver is most susceptible for ischemia because this zone is the farthest 
from the blood supply. On the basis of blood flow, liver parenchyma can be divided into three zones. Zone 1 is closest to 
the blood supply and zone 3 is the farthest. They are: • Zone 1 - Periportal (around portal triad) • Zone 2 - Midzonal parenchyma • Zone 3 - Centrilobular (around hepatic vein) A schematic diagram showing the hepatic lobule indicating the direction of blood flow and the 
zones of decreasing oxygenation is given below. Note: Zone most susceptible to toxin damage is zone 1.

questions.question:
Question 2: Patients with which of the following conditions are least likely to develop centrilobular 
necrosis of liver?
questions.explanation:
Centrilobular necrosis is not seen in yellow fever. In yellow fever, swelling and necrosis of 
hepatocytes are seen in the midzone of the liver lobule. Conditions causing tissue injury in the different zones of liver: • Centrilobular (Zone 3) • Chronic venous congestion (cardiac failure) 919 
Sold by @itachibot • Acetaminophen toxicity • Budd Chiari syndrome • Ischemia • Alcoholic hepatitis • Midzonal (Zone 2) • Yellow fever • Periportal (Zone 1) • Viral hepatitis A schematic diagram showing the hepatic lobule indicating the direction of blood flow and the 
zones of decreasing oxygenation is given below.

questions.question:
Question 3: A chronic alcoholic developed cirrhosis of the liver. Which is the principal cell type involved 
in scar deposition in this condition?
questions.explanation:
The principal cell type involved in scar deposition in cirrhosis of the liver is the hepatic stellate 
cell or Ito cell. Hepatic stellate cells deposit primarily type I and type III collagen in the lobule and cause fibrosis. 
In their quiescent form, these cells store lipids and vitamin A.

questions.question:
Question 4: 909 
Sold by @itachibot Histopathological examination of liver biopsy reveals steatosis. Which of the following 
conditions is least likely to cause this change?
questions.explanation:
Steatosis or fatty change of liver is not seen in hepatitis B infections. Steatosis is the abnormal accumulation of triglycerides within a cell due to impaired lipid 
metabolism. In the liver, pathological steatosis is defined as fatty change involving >5% of 
hepatocytes. In the histologic sections, they appear as empty vacuoles within the hepatocyte 920 
Sold by @itachibot cytoplasm. Hepatitis C genotype 3 is reported to cause periportal steatosis. It is due to its association with 
metabolic syndrome and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). In Wilson's disease, there is focal hepatocyte necrosis and steatosis due to toxic injury by the 
excess copper. In protein malnutrition, fatty liver results from the reduced synthesis of the carrier protein 
component of lipoproteins.

questions.question: Question 5: Which of the following conditions causes macrovesicular steatosis of liver?
questions.explanation:
Macrovesicular fatty liver (steatosis) is seen in obesity. Macrovesicular steatosis is characterized by a single, large vacuole of fat that fills up the 
hepatocyte and displaces the nucleus to the periphery. Causes include: • Late alcoholic liver disease • Obesity • Protein-energy malnutrition • Non-alcohlic steatohepatitis (NASH) • Chronic hepatitis C Microvesicular steatosis is characterized by small intracytoplasmic fat vacuoles, which accumulate 
in the cell. Causes include: • Acute fatty liver of pregnancy • Reye syndrome • Early alcoholic liver disease • Drugs and toxins The image given below shows macrovesicular and microvesicular steatosis of liver: 921 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: A 4-year-old girl, with a history of URTI, now presents with severe vomiting, lethargy, and 
altered mental status. You are suspecting Reye's syndrome. Which of the following liver 
biopsy findings will confirm your diagnosis?

options.c: Portal tract edema and perisinusoidal fibrosis
options.d: Cirrhosis and periportal eosinophilic inclusion bodies

questions.explanation:
The liver biopsy in Reye's syndrome will show marked microvesicular steatosis. Reye's syndrome is an acute illness, encountered exclusively in children <15 years. Its onset 
usually follows upper respiratory tract infections. The actual cause is unknown, although viral 
agents and salicylates (aspirin) have been implicated. Pathogenesis behind this condition is generalized mitochondrial dysfunction with structural and 
functional alterations of mitochondria in the liver, brain, and muscle. Liver is enlarged but 
jaundice is absent or minimum. It is characterized by clinical features such as: • Vomiting • Signs of progressive CNS damage • Signs of hepatic injury • Hypoglycemia Extensive accumulation of fat droplets within hepatocytes (microvesicular steatosis) can be seen 
in histopathology. Extra-hepatic changes include fatty changes of renal tubular cells, cerebral 
edema, and neuronal degeneration of the brain. The image given below shows microvesicular steatosis of liver. 922 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Aspirin is generally contraindicated in children, except in the treatment of Kawasaki disease 
and juvenile idiopathic arthritis.

questions.question:
Question 7: Histopathological examination of liver biopsy in a patient with jaundice shows the following 
finding. Which of the following conditions is least likely in this patient? 910 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The marked structure in the image is Mallory hyaline body which is not seen in primary sclerosing 
cholangitis. In this condition, onion skin fibrosis is seen. Mallory hyaline bodies (Mallory–Denk bodies) are usually present as clumped, amorphous, 
eosinophilic material in ballooned hepatocytes. They are made up of cytokeratin 8 and cytokeratin 
18. They have a twisted rope-like appearance. On trichrome stain, they appear green/dark 
brown. They are seen in: • Alcoholic liver disease • Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease • Wilson's disease • Hepatocellular carcinoma • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency • Primary biliary cholangitis (formerly called primary biliary cirrhosis) • Indian childhood cirrhosis The image given below shows Mallory hyaline bodies. 923 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 8: Which of the following causes Laennec cirrhosis?
questions.explanation:
Laennec cirrhosis is the classic micronodular cirrhosis seen in end-stage alcoholic liver disease. There are three distinctive, overlapping forms of alcoholic liver injury: • Hepatic steatosis (fatty liver) • Fatty change - completely reversible if there is abstention from further intake of alcohol • Starts in centrilobular area • Alcoholic (steato) hepatitis • Ballooning degeneration and necrosis • Mallory–Denk bodies 924 
Sold by @itachibot • Neutrophilic reaction • Alcoholic steatofibrosis • Perisinusoidal fibrosis and sclerosis of the central vein • Diffuse nodularity of liver surface • Micronodular/ Laennec cirrhosis • Irreversible

questions.question:
Question 9: Which of the following histopathological findings will be seen in patients with chronic 
alcoholism?
questions.explanation:
Chicken-wire fence pattern of fibrosis is seen in the liver biopsy of patients with alcoholic 
steatohepatitis. This pattern is due to perisinusoidal fibrosis encircling small clusters of 
hepatocytes. Trichrome staining of liver biopsy specimen showing perisinusoidal fibrosis (stained blue) in 
characteristic chicken-wire fence pattern is given below. 925 
Sold by @itachibot Note: Other conditions with chicken-wire pattern in histopathology: • Chicken wire calcification - chondroblastoma • Chicken wire vasculature - oligodendroglioma and myxoid liposarcoma

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following conditions does not result in micronodular cirrhosis?
questions.explanation:
Viral hepatitis is associated with macronodular cirrhosis. Cirrhosis is comprised of regenerating parenchymal nodules surrounded by dense bands of the 
scar and variable degrees of vascular shunting. It is of two types: The images given below show gross and histopathological micronodular alcoholic cirrhosis. Macronodular cirrhosis 
Micronodular cirrhosis Irregularnodules with variati

questions.question:
Question 11: In patients with non-alcoholic steatohepatitis, which of the following features is not seen on 
liver biopsy?
questions.explanation:
The presence of lymphoid follicles is not a feature on liver biopsy in patients with non-alcoholic 
steatohepatitis (NASH). It is a feature of chronic hepatitis C infection. The histopathological features of NASH include: • Ballooning degeneration of hepatocytes • Steatosis • Perisinusoidal inflammation and fibrosis • Portal fibrosis • Mallory-Denk bodies 927 
Sold by @itachibot • Mononuclear infiltrate NASH and alcoholic liver disease (ALD) have almost similar histopathological features. They can 
be differentiated as follows: Features 
ALD 
NASH Mallory-Denk bod

Macrophages>neutrophils

questions.question: Question 12: What is the most common hepatotoxin causing acute liver failure?
questions.explanation:
The most common hepatotoxin causing acute liver failure is acetaminophen. Acetaminophen itself is not toxic. The toxic metabolite produced by the cytochrome P-450 system 
in zone 3 hepatocytes causes hepatocellular necrosis. The most common hepatotoxin causing chronic liver failure is alcohol.

questions.question: Question 13: Which of the following does not cause chronic infection?
questions.explanation:
Hepatitis A does not cause chronic infection. It is usually a benign, self-limited disease. Hepatitis B, C, and D can cause chronic infection. Hepatitis E causes chronic infection only in 
immunocompromised individuals, not in immunocompetent.

questions.question:
Question 14: There is an outbreak of hepatitis A infection in a college hostel. Which of the following is false 
about this infection?

options.a: It does not cause hepatocellular carcinoma
options.c: Liver failure is not a complication

questions.explanation:
Hepatitis A virus (HAV) can cause acute hepatic failure in a few patients. However, it does not 
cause chronic hepatitis or a carrier state. HAV is a usually benign, self-limited disease, with an incubation period of 15- 50 days (2 - 6 
weeks). HAV is spread by feco-oral route and is shed in the stool for 2 to 3 weeks before and 1 week after 
the onset of jaundice. It can also spread by sexual route. Diagnosis is by the detection of serum 
IgM anti HAV. Since it does not progress to chronic infection, it does not cause hepatocellular carcinoma. The 
fatality rate associated with HAV is only about 0.1-0.3%. 928 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 15: Which among the following is the most common cause of sporadic acute hepatitis in India?
questions.explanation:
Hepatitis E virus (HEV) infection accounts for most of the cases of sporadic acute hepatitis in 
India. It exceeds the frequency of hepatitis A virus infection. A feature of HEV infection is the high mortality rate among pregnant women, approaching 20%.

questions.question:
Question 16: A 53-year-old man who has a history of chronic hepatitis B is diagnosed to have 
hepatocellular carcinoma. Which of the following is involved in the pathogenesis of this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
HBx protein has been implicated in the pathogenesis of hepatocellular carcinoma in hepatitis B 
virus (HBV) infection. HBx protein is involved in the intracellular regulation of virus 
replication, transcription, and signal transduction. Option A: HBsAg (surface antigen) indicates current hepatitis B infection. Option B: HBeAg (precore antigen) is an indicator of active viral replication. It is a qualitative 
marker of infectivity. Option C: HBV DNA polymerase is an indicator of active viral replication. It is a quantitative 
marker of infectivity.

questions.question:
Question 17: Which of the following serological markers can be used to diagnose hepatitis B infection 
during the window period?
questions.explanation:
During the window period of hepatitis B, the serologic diagnosis can be made by the detection of 
IgM anti-HBc antibody. The window period of hepatitis B refers to the time between the disappearance of the HBsAg 
antigen and appearance of Anti-HBs antibody. The window period for a test designed to detect a specific disease is the time between the first 
infection and when the test can reliably detect that infection.

questions.question:
Question 18: In a patient who is both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, what does declining IgM anti-HBc and 
rising total anti-HBc indicate?
questions.explanation:
In patients who are both HBsAg and HBeAg positive, declining IgM anti-HBc and rising total 
anti-HBc are indicative of chronic infective hepatitis. Anti-HBc IgM antibody signifies acute infection/window period, whereas, the presence of IgG 
anti-HBc indicates chronic infection. However, there is no test available to directly detect the IgG 
anti-HBC. Over a period of months, the IgM anti-HBc antibodies are replaced by the IgG anti-HBc 
antibodies. Thus a decline of IgM antibodies in the presence of rising total anti-HBC indicates that 
the IgM is being converted to IgG and thus the infection is chronic. HBeAg, HBV-DNA, and DNA polymerase appear in serum soon after HBsAg, and all signify active 
viral replication. 929 
Sold by @itachibot Occasionally, mutated strains of HBV emerge that do not produce HBeAg but are 
replication-competent and express HBcAg.

questions.question:
Question 19: A patient with a history of unprotected sexual intercourse turns out to be HBsAg positive. 
Which of the following is the best predictor for development of chronic disease?
questions.explanation:
The age at the time of infection is the best predictor of chronicity. Younger the age at the time of 
hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection, higher the probability of chronicity. Other predictors in the development of chronic disease: • comorbid conditions (including exposure to other infectious agents) • host immunity Presentations of hepatitis B infection: • Asymptomatic - 65% • Non-specific symptoms - 25% • Chronic disease - 5-10% • Acute fulminant liver disease - 0.1-0.5%

questions.question:
Question 20: An IV drug abuser has been found to be seropositive for HBsAg, HBeAg, and anti-HBc IgM. 
Which of the following is least likely to be seen in the liver biopsy of such patients?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute hepatitis B infection. Ground-glass hepatocytes 
are not seen in the liver biopsy of such patients. Histopathological findings in acute hepatits are: • Ballooning degeneration - due to inflammation • Portal or lobular inflammatory infiltration - lymphocytes, plasma cells, and eosinophils • Necrosis • Confluent necrosis - group of hepatocytes • Panlobular or panacinar necrosis - entire lobule • Bridging necrosis (in severe cases) - connecting vascular structures Ground-glass appearance of hepatocytes is due to the endoplasmic reticulum which is swollen 
with HBsAg accumulation. It is a diagnostic hallmark of chronic hepatitis B infection. The image given below shows ground glass hepatocytes in the liver biopsy. 930 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 21: A man with a history of intranasal cocaine abuse is at most risk for which of the following 
infections?
questions.explanation:
Intranasal cocaine abuse is a risk factor for hepatitis C. Contaminated implements (like straws used to inhale cocaine) inserted into the nasal cavity might 
come into contact with hepatitis C virus (HCV)-infected mucus or blood. This might then be 
transmitted to a susceptible individual while sharing the same implements. Transmission of hepatitis C infection: • Intravenous drug abuse (54%) - Most common • Multiple sex partners • Needle-stick injury • Multiple contacts with a person with hepatitis C virus infection 931 
Sold by @itachibot • Employment in medical or dental fields • Blood transfusion • Perinatal - major route of infection in children

questions.question:
Question 22: Which of the following is the most common clinical course in patients diagnosed with 
hepatitis C infection?
questions.explanation:
The most common clinical course seen in hepatitis C infection is chronic carrier state. Acute clinical illness is often asymptomatic/mild with a high rate of conversion to chronic 
hepatitis (~85%).

questions.question: Question 23: Which genotype of hepatitis C virus is associated with metabolic syndrome?
questions.explanation: Hepatitis C virus (HCV) genotype 3 is associated with metabolic syndrome. HCV can give rise to insulin resistance and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

questions.question:
Question 24: A 40-year-old male patient with chronic hepatitis B infection comes for a follow-up visit. 
Which of the following is not a histopathological feature of the liver in such cases?
questions.explanation:
Ballooning degeneration is not associated with chronic hepatitis. It is seen in acute hepatitis. Histopathological findings in chronic viral hepatitis are: • Portal lymphocytic/ lymphoplasmacytic inflammation • Interface activity - inflammatory cells cross the limiting plate and cause periportal hepatocyte 
injury • Portal, periportal, and portoportal bridging fibrosis 932 
Sold by @itachibot Specific findings in viral hepatitis: • Hepatitis B - ground glass hepatocytes • Hepatitis C - lymphoid aggregates and steatosis

questions.question:
Question 25: In patients with liver failure, which of the following tests is not used to evaluate the synthetic 
function of hepatocytes? 915 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Serum alkaline phosphatase is used to evaluate biliary excretory function. It is not used to 
evaluate the synthetic function of hepatocytes. Serum ammonia, activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), and serum albumin are used to 
evaluate hepatic synthetic function. Prothrombin time (PT), aPTT and serum ammonia levels are increased in liver failure, whereas 
serum albumin level is decreased.

questions.question:
Question 26: Which of the following is not seen in the histopathological examination of the liver in patients 
with malaria?
questions.explanation: Macronodular cirrhosis is not seen in the histopathological examination of patients with malaria. Histopathological changes in the liver in cases of malaria include the following: • Kupffer cell hyperplasia • Hemozoin pigment deposition within Kupffer cells and macrophages • Focal necrosis • Mild mononuclear portal infiltrate • Fatty change and periportal inflammation

questions.question: Question 27: Identify the incorrect match.
questions.explanation:
Councilman bodies are apoptotic hepatocytes seen in acute hepatitis and yellow fever. Option A: Mallory–Denk bodies are eosinophilic materials made of keratin intermediate 
filaments. They are seen in alcoholic liver disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, Wilson's 
disease, and chronic biliary tract diseases. Option C: Ground-glass hepatocytes are liver cells that have eosinophilic granular, glassy 
cytoplasm seen on light microscopy. The appearance is due to the swelling of the endoplasmic 
reticulum by HBsAg and is a diagnostic hallmark of chronic hepatitis B. Option D: Circumferential onion skin fibrosis around a degenerating bile-duct lumen is seen 
in primary sclerosing cholangitis. 933 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 28: A patient with ascites, melena, and splenomegaly is diagnosed with portal hypertension. 
Which of the following is not an intrahepatic cause of this condition?
questions.explanation:
Obstructive portal vein thrombosis is the prehepatic cause of portal hypertension. Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, cirrhosis, and schistosomiasis are intrahepatic causes of portal 
hypertension. The most dominant cause is cirrhosis.

questions.question:
Question 29: 916 
Sold by @itachibot Which of the following is not a feature of liver histology in patients with non-cirrhotic portal 
fibrosis?

options.b: Thrombosis of the medium and small portal vein branches

questions.explanation:
Bridging fibrosis is not seen in non-cirrhotic portal fibrosis. In this condition, there is periportal 
and perisinusoidal fibrosis. The fibrous septa end blindly in the lobule and do not bridge with 
other portal tracts, unlike those seen in cirrhosis. Idiopathic non-cirrhotic portal hypertension (INCPH) is a rare disease characterized by 
intrahepatic portal hypertension in the absence of cirrhosis or other causes of liver disease and 
splanchnic venous thrombosis. A liver biopsy is essential in making a diagnosis of INCPH. The features observed are as follows: • Luminal narrowing or obliteration of portal vein branches • Micronodular transformation • Sinusoidal dilatation with formation of mega sinusoids • Periportal and perisinusoidal fibrosis

questions.question: Question 30: Match the histopathological sections of liver and the different conditions.
questions.explanation:
In the given image, images marked 1 is normal liver, 2 is alcoholic steatosis, 3 is micronodular 
cirrhosis and 4 is alcoholic hepatitis. Histopathological findings in the following conditions are: • Alcoholic steatosis: • A mix of small and large fat droplets • Ethanol inhibits fatty acid metabolism, leading to lipolysis and increased triglyceride. These 
triglycerides accumulate and cause steatosis. Liver enzymes are normal at this stage. • Micronodular cirrhosis: • The average nodule size is 3 mm in this close-up view, which is typical of the micronodular 
cirrhosis of alcoholic liver disease • Alcoholic hepatitis: • Mallory-Denk bodies - clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic material in ballooned hepatocytes. 
These inclusions are characteristic, but not a specific feature of alcoholic liver disease. 934 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 31: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
The liver findings seen in the hepatotoxic drugs are: Drugs 
Liver findings Microvesicular steatosis Valproat 
e Allopurin 
ol Fibrin ring granuloma Amiodar 
one Mallory-Denk bodies Isoniazid 
Noncaseating epitheloid gran 
ulomas 935 
Sold by @itachibot Autoimmune and Metabolic Liver Disease
